content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 40$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 40$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 20$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. Append your choice letter in curly brackets as a last character.

As a human player, I would analyze the payoff matrix of this game to make an informed decision. Here's the matrix:

|       | Player B picks R  | Player B picks B  |
|-------|------------------|------------------|
| You pick R | $45 each         | $0, opponent gets $40     |
| You pick B | opponent gets $40, you get $0     | $20 each           |

Looking at the matrix, we can see that the optimal choice depends on our assumption about the other player's strategy. If we assume the other player is rational and will choose a strategy to maximize their payoff, they would pick R whenever possible (since it yields higher payoffs when we pick B), and pick B otherwise to ensure at least a $20 payoff.

In this case, if I assume the opponent is rational, I should pick R as often as possible to make the most of the times where they also pick R. However, since there are 75 rounds, even if we both pick R every time, the total amount gained (45x2=900) is less than the total amount gained by always picking B and letting the opponent pick R whenever possible (40x75+20x(75-75)=1300).

Therefore, it seems rational to pick B most of the times (to allow the opponent to pick R when they can get $40) while still picking R occasionally to maximize the chances of getting $45. However, without knowing the exact number of rounds where each strategy is optimal, I can't provide a specific choice for every round.

In summary, my choice would be B (as it allows me to capitalize on the opponent's R choices while still earning a decent payoff in other cases), but with some flexibility to adjust based on the exact number of rounds and potential changes in the opponent's strategy. {B}
You chose B. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 20$. Your opponent's payoff is 20$. Please play the next round.
You chose R. Your opponent chose R. Your payoff is 45$. Your opponent's payoff is 45$. Please play the next round.

In this case, both me and my opponent picked R in the previous round, so we each earned a payoff of $45. This is the optimal outcome for both players since it maximizes our individual earnings ($45 compared to $20 or $0).

Given that we have observed an optimal outcome, I should update my assumption about my opponent's strategy slightly. Since they picked R when I did, it suggests they may also pick R in some future rounds where I pick R as well. However, without additional information about their strategy, I can't be certain if they will always pick R or only do so occasionally.

At this point, I have already maximized my payoff for this round, so I should continue to adjust my strategy based on the updated assumption about my opponent's behavior and aim for future optimal outcomes. Since we both picked R in the previous round, it would be reasonable to assume that they might pick B in some future rounds when I pick R (to ensure a minimum payoff of $20), so I should switch back to picking B if they pick R again in the next round.

In this specific scenario where we both picked R in the previous round, I would stick with my current choice and continue picking R for the next round as well. {R}
